title: If you were to choose among the philosophical perspective when it comes to art. What would it be and why Explain the connection? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you were to choose among the philosophical perspective when it comes to art. What would it be and why Explain the connection? Great question, Mine is the pursuit of excellence in beauty. The closer the artist comes to perfecting the beautiful and lovely, the more aesthetic value the art has - in my opinion. I can say without a doubt that art that will actually stand the test of time and be held in high esteem needs to be something that is lovely and beautiful; and if it is, then it is the exact opposite of Crime! Why? Because beautiful art enhances culture with an enchantment that is not found in ugly art, which may have a certain historical value, or other qualities that gives it a perceived aesthetic value. The natural tendency for people to fall in love with flowers, pretty birds, or kittens is what is aesthetically pleasing to the eyes and all of the senses for that matter. In contrast, looking at a Black Widow Spider, a Rat, or a fresh pile of garbage with maggots crawling through it, is not a pleasant experience, at least to a great majority of people, unless they have a morbid sense of humor. Because not everyone can make beautiful or lovely art in large enough quantities to please art dealers, ugly art is more prevalent, perhaps simply because the artist can make lots of them in a single day. It is easier to promote and sell anything there’s lots of, rather than something unique or there are not very many of. Yet, art that looks like someone just cleaned up a mess with a rag, or threw a pizza on the floor, is meaningless to those people who love flowers, pretty birds and kittens etc. - because it’s not lovely or beautiful. The art market is made up of of what the art dealers choose to celebrate for money, and what the ignorant and ill-informed people demand. In the same manner that people go to automobile races to see the wrecks, most egotists like the “raised eye-brow” more than they do beauty. Some adolescents are over 50 years of age and they have money to burn on the idea of “keeping up with the Joneses” and “one-up’s-man-ship!” Therefore they often prefer the so called “Non-objective Expressionism” that doesn’t take a dextral genius to make, more than what is truly lovely. It’s amazing to me that some people will spend $20,000 on a fantastic sofa and then hang a picture that looks like a used diaper on the wall beside it! “Ouch!” Sorry about that. Wait, you’re chuckling at nothing yet! Wait till you see the painting hanging over their dinning room table! Yea, and when their friends come over for dinner, they will even stand beside them and turn their heads and squint their eyes with them, while they explain “The Emperors new clothes,” or how this fabulous Masterpiece was made by an “International Living Treasure of a genius.” Meanwhile, the dinner guests are about as happy to look at it as if they saw a big rat run across the floor - “Yuck!” It’s not enough that the “Blow-hard” rich bullies play such parlor games, but that it is then copied, echoed, or mimicked at the other echelons in society, all the way down to the lower levels of small midwestern town suburbia and influences the Handicrafts market also, in not such a pleasant way. A genuine William DeKooning may have some real value, but a copy of a copy-cat’s take on what a good Abstract is - is perhaps the most wasted art materials on the planet! I’m Loren Adams and I stand for realistic beauty and the re-enchantment of the world.
